Author: cletus
Content:
This is really an obvious non-story. Smart phones came into existence because they became possible with the (currently) relentless march of Moore's Law. That same law and increasing demand is predictably driving down costs. Shock, horror.

As for those bemoaning the demise of feature phones, that too is inevitable. It suits the usage pattern of some. Also cheap phones will live for a long time due to markets in developing countries where price is a more important factor.

Also for those saying the data plans and service costs are a barrier: the US is a mobile backwater (compared to any other OECD nation). Service is woeful, costs are ludicrous... It's simply ridiculous. Being charged for receiving calls? Receiving SMSs?!? Huge data costs. Lack of data Goering (eg a small woeful 100-200mb plan and then an unlimited or 2-5gb plan with a huge step up and nothing in between).

In the US you're paying realistically $60/month minimum (more if you want to tether!). In Australia I'd pay as little as half that for superior coverage and service quality. In Asia it'd probably be even less.

I expect in the developed world dmartphones will outsell feature phones within 3 years.

Author: harryh
Content:
Yes, on occasion. We've combatted this in a couple of different ways:

1) Rewriting code to make fewer memory allocations or, in some cases, allocate memory for shorter periods of time (so it doesn't get promoted to a longer lived heap)

2) Garden variety GC tuning. Tune the various heap sizes, and GC algorithms used.

Author: kansando
Content:
As a lapsed superconductivity physicist, I hate to burst the bubble. In the community there has been a long-standing joke about USOs, Unidentified Superconducting Objects, and it is well known that just because you see "Signs of Superconductivity" does not prove that something is superconducting.

There are really three questions at hand: 1> Does the sample show the Meissner effect, 2> Does it show zero resistance, and 3> Is it stable under addition of impurities. It turns out that for most ceramic compounds, even if 1 is true, 2 and 3 are often not true. For example, the Cuprates (the first to cross the 77K mark) actually have a higher resistance close to the critical temperature than copper. Point 3 is especially damning as sensitivity to impurities also means you can't draw these things into wires (certainly not wires you can bend) as the very act of bending may introduce defects that change local concentration of ingredients and hurt the superconductivity.

So the burden of proof remains very high, and the small blurb is very underwhelming.

Author: iworkforthem
Content:
I have my doubts if smartphones can ever cost the same as regular phones. Like @ams6110 said smartphones come cheaper only after it is contracted with a 2 yrs data plan, cause this would only make $$$ sense for both the carrier and the manufacturer.

ps: I own a iPhone 4 which come heavily subsidized with a 2 yr data plan and a $35 non-smartphone which I bought, without any long term contract.

Also, another issue with smartphone is the battery life. They drain out really fast, finding a charger recharge a mobile twice a day just dun make sense in quite a lot of places in the world.

Till these issues are resolved, and unless countries are willingly to upgrade of their telecommunication infrastructure, my guess is that smartphones and non-smartphones are likely to coexist for a quite number of years. Sure, developed countries will continue to upgrade to something like Japan and South Korea.

Author: yywt
Title: Things I've learned or believe.
Content:
Some time ago, I decided to write down things I learned, realized, or believed as they occurred to me. I figured that a handful of these may resonate with some people in this community. These are ordered, somewhat arbitrarily, by number of characters, descending.

-------------------------------------

A failure of certain information to get elicited from one source and delivered to another constitutes an information distribution problem. Information distribution problems, when solved, have been the basis for the many of the largest technology businesses.

There are things I own that I won't sell but I would rent. Similarly there are things I wouldn't buy but would rent temporarily. Temporary ownership can be made possible by a better rental market for goods.

The day an organization starts to de-value the intellectual superiority of one idea over another is the day the operational focus of the company tilts towards internal, not external, needs.

The best online advertising models don't feel like advertising to the consumer. They feel like well-intentioned purchasing assistants. That's where the ad models on the web need to go.

Good companies often have a lot of extremely smart people with vast knowledge in domains outside of the company's line of business. That knowledge should be used.

When someone says something won't work, ask them what, very specifically, about the idea won't work, determine if that is indeed a problem, then fix it if so.

When a class of entities exhibit little differentiation from one another, the class itself is devalued in the eyes of those not within the class.

When web people talk about conversion rates, I have to wonder if their denominator is the same denominator that those "converting" behave on.

Individual preferences do not exist. All preferences are determined at least in part, if not in full, by mimicking what others seem to want.

Decision making is not about viscerally concluding what's right. It's about understanding what changes when you pick one option vs another.

I've seen homeless people ask homeless people for money or food and get it. People are generous to those whose hardship they understand.

Think about all the occasions someone could want your product. Figure out how to get your message to them at those specific occasions.

Making earth better is fundamentally more important than money. The latter shouldn't be understated as a means to the former though.

The end product of creative work is usually consumed from start to finish. Producing the work in that order rarely makes sense.

Doing anything simply and effectively is extremely hard. So give people who succeed at being simple some serious credit.

When you're pitching a startup or idea, talk about how you're going to change the cultural landscape of the world.

Having things to talk about can not be overstated enough as the basis for friendship developing among strangers.

Language is right up there with functionality and design in terms of criticality of getting right in a product.

Don't do things you don't have a shot at being the absolute best at. Pursue furiously those things you can be.

You must convince other people to do things you want them to do in order to get anything of magnitude done.

Simplifying is hard is because it involves acknowledging that an aspect of your idea isn't worth including.

We all share the same time, but not the same place. No matter where you are, we both observe this second.

The way to feel comfortable taking risks is to simply avoid the risks whose nature you don't understand.

Becoming famous involves fundamentally treating yourself as a brand that you work tirelessly to promote.

The way to make money is to charge people for stuff that you can prevent them from obtaining for free.

Creative thinking should be done alone. Problem solving should be done in groups. I'm not sure why.

Solve the "get people to care" problem, and you'll succeed at anything you set out to do.

The best way of decreasing your likelihood of failure is to not speak or do much.

Developers think in terms of functionality. Everyone else thinks in terms of fun.

Creative work only succeeds when only the creator could have thought of it.

Whatever you're making, make people believe you love nothing more than it.

You should invest in things you believe in until you break down to tears.

Change is hard because it takes you away from that which is familiar.

People are impressed by clarity, not complexity.

The only useful feedback is criticism.

Everyone's goal in life is to matter.

twitter.com/niknir

Author: reappear
Content:
The ramp video is fun, but i don't think it belongs in the same bin as other "optical illusions".

Yes, visual cortex failed, and it failed where a god would succeed (succeed in finding the simplest interpretation and making a sharp bet on that interpretation). But the most surprising optical illusions present a far lower bar which visual cortex then still fails to clear.

Often, they exploit what must be some specific implementation detail of visual cortex.

Often, they feel really weird from the inside. Sometimes they force competing interpretations, sometimes a single interpretation which turns out to be obviously wrong.

So i guess it's probably right to insist that an inference engine's optical illusions be a subset of its koans. At my level, the ramps are no koan, just a (funny and clever) lie.

Author: Bud
Content:
The reason that Craigslist is popular is because there is no BS involved. It's plaintext. You click on somethingâit loads. It does not ask you where you are or try to sneak info from your browser. It doesn't stop loading while it's doing goofy Microsoft stuff. It doesn't stop loading while it harvests your personal info. It's dead simple.

I'd suggest you emulate this, above all else.
